content.description:
Two bolts start is the crux edging on tiny crystals plentiful enough to make up for nearly non existent hands. Climbing goes up to a finger crack through a small roof, then more bolts on the face with lower angle moves on more crystals. Not sure how the FA did the finish, but I linked into another crack up to Squatters rights to top out as it seemed most logical.  

Immediately right of squatters rights
Mostly bolts, single rack would be more than enough. Climbers confident at the grade could lead with just some finger size cams as the top out left is only low 5th

Climb the nice steep finger crack with some technical movement, one bolt at the top after the crack fizzles out. Can easily be top-roped by walking around to the left.



Far left side of Funarama crag, on an independent cliff with one striking finger crack on it.

SR

Bourdon gives this a 10b, but I didn't think it was any harder than Sunshine Chimney, the p2 squeeze chimney on Rock on or the chimney on Birds of Prey, all 5.8. Lots of ledges and rests, only a few moments of real chimney moves. A fine activity, but nothing noteworthy.

The obvious chimney left of all the rest of the climbing.
1 bolt and standard rack to a #1 C4. Raw bolt hangers at the top, so the second will want to walk off (climber's left).

A high quality crack that takes great gear.  The start is the crux and looks harder than it is.

This is the very obvious crack right in front of the trail that joins the crag to the loop trail.
Finger to hand sized cams and nuts.  Bolted anchor.

Climb the finger crack to the left of Fun (the stepped hand crack).  More climbing, and more secure, than it might first appear.

Anchors abound on the ramp above the slab at the top, and can be accessed by a fixed rope to the right.

It's a short route, but worth a run up while you're waiting on a nearby route.

More gear than it appears from below, though it is not generous; mostly finger-size.

Immediately left of Funarama is an obvious right-trending diagonal ramp. A few face moves get you onto the ramp, which is climbed easily to a junction with Funarama on the ledge where that's route crack dead-ends. The original finish of this route is the same as Funarama's crux, up the bouldery continuation of the ramp. The new finish cleaned by Harry and Robin takes a left-trending diagonal crack that veers out left from the junction ledge to a new bolted anchor on another ledge about 8m left. Going this way keeps the grade to a more consistent 5.8

Just left of the straight-in crack of Funarama at Funarama Left.
Gear to 2"

Follow a straight in quality thin crack to a ledge at the point where the ramp of Funarampa joins in from the left and where the crack you have been following suddenly ends. Move left slightly and work up and back right to the top, technical and cruxy to finish.

At the left end of Funarama Left, the obvious vertical crack.
Gear to 1"

Slabby arete climbing.  Worth doing in the neighborhood.

Slabby arete just left of a big gash.
4 bolts.  Anchor is all the way at the top and doesn't have chains.  Rap the anchor to the left.

Climb in & around a stepped hand crack that leans a bit left.  

Bolted anchors abound on the ramp at the top, and can be accessed by a fixed rope to the right.

Short, but worth a quick run up while you wait for things nearby.

Middle of Funarama:  there are several short slight left-leaning, stepped cracks.
Std rack

Start left of Juneuary below a bolt. Clip the bolt then move right to a crux with a diagonal thin crack. Climb this thin crack to where it meeta another thin crack diagonalling back left. Follow this (same as the later route Juneuary) up and left to a ledge just below the top of the cliff. Here, and this you must do to claim the tick of Futurama, step out onto the blankish headwall to the right with smooth foot cross-throughs on a couple of flaring seams (second crux) and on up to the top. Very footwork dependant on the last few moves, not much to pull on with your hands. Right in the middle of Funarama cliff. Used to be just right of a giant burnt log but Hevy Duty removed the log to squeeze more climbs in.
Now just the second line right of the deep corner dividing Funarama Left from Funarama Centre.

Rap anchors on top. Two bolts and gear to 1"

Start up left leaning seam before clipping two bolts on the face. An easier section at two cracks leads to more bolts up and left. 


Quickdraws, some small cams for before the first bolt.

Start up a thin seam that trends right, clip a bolt, and then up the left trending finger crack. Crux is at the bolt.

Gear is good the whole way, despite appearances.  Nothing bigger than a #0.5 camalot needed.  A purple C3 went in nicely towards the top.  There is a 5.6/5.7 unprotected move to gain the anchor.

The furthest right route at Funarama, protection can feel a little spaced but is there when you need it. Begin at a slabby ramp and climb past the first bolt on the right then straight up on intermittent cracks and ledges with a few face moves past two small gear cracks and a second bolt. The crux is the last moves above the second bolt up to the welcome jugs of the belay ledge.

The farthest right and farthest downhill route at Funarama Right-Hand
Two bolts plus a medium wire and a 3/4" cam. Two bolts at top for anchor, traverse climbers left on ledge to First Class rap station for descent.

Primary a crack climb, there's a point in the middle where it becomes blank (hence the name).  The various cracks you link up take textbook gear placements.

In the upper section of the crag, this route starts just right of a stump, directly below a series of three diagonal cracks at the top of the crag.  The route, as done in the FA, goes more-or-less straight up at the top, touching all three of the upper cracks.  Recent scrubbing and anchor placement might draw you left on the first of those cracks, but that take the grade and the fun out of it.
Eats finger sized nuts and cams.  A few hand sized pieces can be used.

climbs.name: Ramapithecus
climbs.fa: D Brayshaw J Ford C Fleet 1999

content.description:
Climb the opening moves of Funarampa and pull out left over a bulge on finger flakes. Climb up thin cracks and ripples past two bolts. Where the features blank out, tenuous slab moves lead to an upper ledge. Climb a short double hand crack to the top and rap anchors. 
  
 Originally climbed as a boltless headpoint by the FA team after they forgot the drill; the bolts were added the following spring.  

At the left end of Funarama Left, straight up from the bottom of the Funarampa ramp. A newer route called Pliocene Ape climbs between Funarampa and Ramapithecus and features similar climbing at a similar grade.
Gear to 1" - include some RP sized nuts and thin cams - and two bolts

This climb is something of a one-move-wonder, but is still fun.  The move at the bolt is surprisingly difficult and most would agree harder than the grade of 5.10a given in the guide book.  The right-trending crack after the bolt is easier to walk across, but hand-traversing it is fun and ups the grade to about 5.10d.

Just right of Point Break on a wavy slab, easily distinguished by the single bolt below a right-trending crack.
One bolt plus some finger-sized cams for the horizontal crack.  A few nuts and hand-sized pieces for the rest.

Climb intermittent hand cracks left of Squatters Rights to a very small roof. step up over this and face climb, zig-zagging past two bolts to gain a upper ledge and a short finishing crack. Good varied climbing with interesting route finding at the crux.

Immediately left of Squatters Rights and right of the Backhoe Chimney at the uphill side of Funarama Right
Gear to 2" and 2 bolts

A long straight crack at the left end of Funarama Right. The crux moves are off the ground with some face holds and intermittent cracks, then it is a long hand to fist crack to the top with great jamming and plentiful protection opportunities.


Left end of Funarama Right about 1m right of the deep chimney dividing Funarama Right from Funarama Centre

Gear to 3"

Climb the discontinuous left leaning cracks to the right of Point Blank. When the cracks end, clip a bolt and continue up the smooth slab split by a horizontal crack. Two additional bolts provide protection above the horizontal crack. Exit the slab onto an easier hand crack that leads to the top. 
  
 The crux of this climb is at the second and third bolt on the slab. Note that the start of this climb is shared with the climb September Song.

Funarama, to the left of Point Blank
3 bolts, standard rack

climbs.name: Working Class
climbs.fa: FA D Brayshaw M Buda 2002  FFA John Millar D Brayshaw 2003

content.description:
Begin up First Class and move left on a left-arching crack/ramp to a ledge (a newer route called Armspan 5.12b/c or 11- A0 crosses through here). Climb cracks off the ledge to a cruxy bolted slab move to another ledge (short 11a/b crux), then up a leftward diagonalling crack. Where it ends, finish either left up a short corner or take the original finish right a few meters and up to the top.  
  
 The route is consistently 5.9 except for the crux past the bolt and can easily be done as a 5.9 A0 by pulling on the bolt.

At the lower end of Funarama Right, left of the straight in thin crack of First Class. A newer mostly bolted line called Armspan climbs directly up to the lower ledge, crosses WC and then climbs between it and FC to the top. Another mostly bolted new route called Classless (10d) climbs left of WC and immediately right of Squatters Rights.
Gear to 2" and one bolt

Freshly scrubbed (2009), this formerly obscure area is now a fine little destination.  As with most Smoke Bluffs areas is less-than-vertical, but it offers some excellent finger cracks along with undulating slabs.  Some of the slabs are testpieces of the genre.  It is broken into an upper (left) and a lower (right) area separated by a short stretch trail. 
  
 There appear to be quite a number of new routes here too recent to to be in the 2005 McLane guide book.  Most are on the lower crag, although there is one very grim looking bolted slab on the upper crag. 
  
 New route descriptions are likely in the new route binder at Climb On on Squamish.  One new route is on the left side of the lower crag and is distinguished by being just right of the dirty gully and having two or three bolts in the thin and slabby upper half.  It's reasonably fun and goes at about 10c.
